abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Biodiversity
            Conservation Project for Russia are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: securing budgets for conservation at the
            regional level as soon as possible. As with many
            conservation projects supported by the Bank/global
            environment facility (GEF), a commitment by the government
            to allocating resources for the longer term needs to be
            secured and arrangements for a stable funding mechanism
            stipulated and agreed during project preparation. While the
            budget for environment conservation of the model regions has
            seen increases, overall allocations for conservation have
            been reduced. Using a programmatic approach for complex and
            challenging conservation projects. A programmatic approach
            or another phasing instrument may be more appropriate in
            obtaining tractability in the short-term and sustainability
            in the long-term. This will have been especially appropriate
            given the 60 major tasks and numerous sub-tasks spread
            across Russia, involving national, regional and local
            governments and staff from Non-governmental Organizations
            (NGOs), academia and the general public. Integrating
            conservation with regional/local planning commensurate with
            projected needs to conserve biodiversity at ecosystem,
            species and genetic levels. For future projects, priority
            should be given to better integration of protected areas
            (PAs) with the growth of local economies based upon enhanced
            ecosystem services and to adapting emerging tools to support
            restoration of ecological units, especially for application
            in the most heavily degraded agrarian regions.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, substantial institutional
            development impacts, accompanied by satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons on
            sector development issues indicate that through the
            development of Regional Conservation Strategies and Action
            Plans, regional coordinating centers, small grants programs,
            and others,  proved instrumental in addressing conservation
            issues at the regional scope. Although there is high quality
            technical expertise in Russia to support implementation
            ofnational and regional conservation programs,  the local
            institutional "infrastructure" for providing
            respective consulting and advisory services however,  is
            underdeveloped. This translates into the need to facilitate
            institutional change, adapting processes (such as
            procurement) to the prevailing market conditions,
            particularly outside Moscow, which would eventually result
            in more cost-effective project solutions in future
            biodiversity operations.  Moreover,  interaction and
            coordination between protected areas, and regional/local
            public education authorities should  maximize the
            effectiveness of the protected area-based education
            programs. Lessons on the operational context suggest, and
            reinforce the need for an early procurement and co-financing
            planning; for monitoring project performance indicators
            (particularly on technical issues); to foster staff
            continuity; and, to benefit from a  sector-wide review of
            project impacts, incorrelation with other Bank, and non-Bank
            implemented projects, contributing effectively, within the
            country assistance strategy (CAS) framework, in each
            specific sector.

            CONSERVATION PROJECT,TF035523-RUSSIA - PROPOSED SUSTAINABLE

5084055.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Biodiversity
            Conservation Project is to assist the Russian Federation
            maintain optimum levels of biodiversity in accordance with
            the principles of economic and environmentally sound
            sustainable development. The project will assist in ensuring
            the enhanced protection of biodiversity, within and outside
            protected areas, in conformance with the government's
            obligations under the Convention of Biological Diversity.
            The project will include the following three components: 1)
            strategic overview consisting of: (a) national and regional
            biodiversity strategies; (b) biodiversity policy support;
            and (c) biomonitoring information system; 2) strengthening
            of protected area systems including: (a) institutional
            support; (b) operations and planning; (c) public support and
            education programs; (d) ecosystem protection; and (e)
            training; and 3) Lake Baikal regional program comprising:
            (a) inter-regional activities; (b) regional activities; and
            (c) local biodiversity activities.
